text:
In the nearly 400-year
history of Harvard,

this is our first
virtual commencement.

Let's pray it will
also be our last.

This is also the
tenth and last time

that I will have the honor
of speaking to a graduating

class as dean of this school,
as I plan to step down
at the end of this year.

This is certainly
not how any of us

had hoped to celebrate
this occasion.

But let's set aside
any disappointments
we might be experiencing.

--to honor the
virtual Class of 2020.

--Let's be grateful
that we are alive.

Let's be grateful
that despite the most

unexpected interruption, we
did finish the school year.

I am grateful to you,
the Class of 2020.

You have already
inspired us by how

you have risen to solve some
of the immediate challenges
of this global pandemic.

Yet, you will need to
do more, much more.

Seventy-three years ago
at Harvard's commencement

ceremony, General
George Marshall

announced a plan to
rebuild the world economy

after the devastation wrought
by World War II, what became
known as the Marshall Plan.

Today, we face a global
economy that has to be rebuilt,

companies that need to
be restarted, revitalized

and restructured, supply chains
that need to be redesigned,

and markets that need
to be reinvented.

We need something that is
equivalent to a new Marshall
Plan.

You, the Class of 2020,
are as prepared as anyone

to meet the challenges
the world is facing now,

to come up with ideas
that will save our planet,

create more opportunities
for those who see none,

foster unity instead of
discord, rebuild society's

trust in capitalism,
and increase prosperity

and the quality of life for
people all across the world.
I wish you all luck.

I wish you love,
and I will miss you.

We will all be rooting for
you to become leaders who
make a difference in the world.
Congratulations.
Congratulations to you all

on your graduation from
Harvard Business School.
